required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Continuous Positive Airway Pressure and Oxygen Concentration on Measurement of Rapid Shallow Breathing Index
clinical_study.official_title: Effect of Continuous Positive Airway Pressure and Oxygen Concentration on Measurement of Rapid Shallow Breathing Index

brief_summary.textblock: To compare the rapid shallow breathing index (RSBI) values, the incidence of adverse reactions, and the predictive accuracy measured under 5 different ventilator strategies in the same patient group.

detailed_description.textblock: 98 ready for weaning patients were included and divided into success (n=71) and failure (n=27) groups based upon their weaning outcome. Before weaning, the RSBI values were determined under the patients disconnecting from the ventilator (RA-no ventilator) and still connecting to the ventilator with 4 different settings (fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) 21 or 40% combined with continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) 0 or 5 cm H2O). The patients were extubated after completing the weaning trials. Successful weaning was defined as patients free from the ventilator for over 48 hours.

primary_outcome.measure: The patients connecting or disconnecting to the ventilators affected the RSBI values but not their predictive accuracies.
primary_outcome.time_frame: Before the patient processing weaning trials

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes in FiO2 and CPAP settings have no effect on RSBI values but ventilator methods with FiO2 21% have higher incidence of adverse reactions.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Before the patient processing weaning trials

arm_group.description: group (success or failure), case number, measurement method

study_pop.textblock: respiratory therapy intensive Care unit in a medical center

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- intubated medical patients with mechanically ventilated more than 48 hours
- clinically ready for weaning
- Glasgow coma scales were at least 8
- their ventilator settings were: assist-controlled, pressure support (PS)or synchronized intermittent mandatory ventilation plus PS mode, FiO2 40% or less, positive end-expiratory pressure 5 cm H2O or less, and sensitivity setting on 1 L/min. Their arterial blood gases results were acceptable
Exclusion Criteria:
- having ongoing lung or neuromuscular disease and signs of increased intracranial pressure

overall_official.affiliation: School of Respiratory Therapy, Taipei Medical University, Taipei, Taiwan, ROC

facility.name: Respiratory Therapy Intensive Care Unit, Taipei Veterans General Hospital

responsible_party.name_title: Mauo-Ying Bien PhD, RPT, RRT/Assistant Professor
responsible_party.organization: School of Respiratory Therapy, Taipei Medical University, Taipei, Taiwan
